awd_titl_txt: Co-robotic Games for Low Resource Learners
awd_abstract_narration:
As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative research, approaches and resources for use in a variety of settings. Robots and robotics excite and challenge youths and adults. Unfortunately, the cost of purchasing robots or building useful robots is prohibitive for many low resource individuals and groups. This project will relieve this expense and provide an opportunity for resource limited individuals to experience the thrilling aspects of robotics by building a computer game that simulates robotic action. This project uses co-robotics wherein the participating player programs an avatar to assist in a symbiotic manner to achieve the goals of the game and participant. The game will provide access to the ideas and concepts such as programing, computational thinking and role assumption. The overarching goals are (1) to engage low-resource learners in STEM education through robotics in out-of-school spaces, and (2) to update the field of robotics-base STEM education to integrate the co-robotics paradigm.

This project is designed to gain knowledge on how co-robotics can be used in the informal education sector to facilitate the integration of computational science with STEM topics and to expand the educational use of co-robotics. Because the concept of co-robotics is new, a designed-based research approach will be used to build theoretical knowledge and knowledge of effective interventions for helping  participants learn programing and computational thinking. Data will be collected from several sources including surveys, self-reports, in game surveys, pre and post-tests. These data collection efforts will address the following areas: Technology reliability, Resolution of cognitive tension around co-play, Accelerate discovery and initial engagement, Foster role-taking and interdependence with co-robots, Investigate social learning, and Validate measures using item response theory analysis. The DBR study questions are:
1.What design principles support the development of P3Gs that can effectively attract initial engagement in a free-choice OST space that offers large numbers of competing options? 2.What design principles support a P3G gameplay loop that enables learning of complex skills, computational thinking and co-robotics norms, and building of individual and career interest over the course of repeated engagement?
3.What design principles support P3Gs in attaining a high rate of re-engagement within low-resource OST settings? 4.What kinds of positive impact can P3Gs have on their proximal and distal environment? In addition, the project will research these questions about design: 1.What technical and game design features are needed to accommodate technological interruption? 2.What design elements or principles mitigate competition for cognitive resources between real-time play and understanding the co-robotic's behavior in relation to the code the player wrote for it? 3.What design elements are effective at getting learners in OST settings to notice and start playing the game? 4.What designs are effective at encouraging learners to engage with challenging content, particularly the transition from manual play to co-play? 5.What design elements help players develop a stake in the role the game offers? 6.What social behaviors emerge organically around a P3G prototype that is not designed to evoke specific social interactions?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to update the mode of robotics portrayed in CS-STEM programming games from isolated self-driving automata, to modern interactive and collaborative partner agents. We chose collaborative co-design with youth at afterschool centers in marginalized communities to authentically engage these young people as equitable partners in the design of the games – both as a form of inclusion, and to produce games more relevant to youth audiences.

While pandemic closures disrupted our initial plans, we were ultimately able to complete six co-design cycles that produced playable prototypes, four of which were released to the public. These games can be accessed online at https://www.cs2n.org/u/mp/badge_pages/1567.

Intellectual Merit

We made findings in two principal areas. First, we established that collaborative robot agents – cobots – could be included as programmable partners in web-accessible digital games, and unpacked what this meant in practice. Whereas we initially thought of “cobot games” as a genre focused on robot interactions, work on multiple cobot titles led us to realize that cobot programming was better characterized as a gameplay mechanic applicable to nearly any game design. In fact, the co-designed cobot games produced under the award included an action tower defense game, an open-world driving game, a pest cleanup game in third-person perspective, a rhythm game, and a haunted house horror game for teens. Cobot programming in these games was most successful when given to players to use in achieving their other gameplay goals. Allowing cobots to inherit the goals, “nouns”, and “verbs” of the overall game helped players understand and accept the cobot as part of that game (Higashi, et al., 2021). Framing cobots as a reusable mechanic also enabled reuse of the browser-based block programming technology stack.

Second, while we had not set out intending to develop new research methods, our decision to design each cobot game with a different afterschool site in our partner’s network turned out to be consequential. Implementing the same co-design process at different sites and with different communities meant that the program had to be adapted for each setting. Retrospective analysis of these adaptations allowed us to make inferences about substantively impactful elements of each context, and even piece together cohesive archetypes of afterschool spaces (Solyst, et al., 2023). Our experiences conducting comparable co-design programs across sites also provided practical insight into researcher-as-instrument in design-based research (Uchidiuno, et al, 2021). Conducting research at multiple sites with the same (initial) process and drawing inferences based on grounded patterns of site-specific adaptation may have general methodological merit as a pattern we call Comparative Design-Based Research (cDBR).

Broader Impact

The co-design program was conducted with approximately 100 elementary, middle, and high school aged youth at five afterschool programs serving low-income, racially minoritized, gentrified, and rural communities spread across two counties. The project supported one postdoctoral scholar (who subsequently became a research professor at a different prestigious US university) and several undergraduate researchers, including one REU student.

The games produced through the research are available to the public free of charge on our website, CS2N.org. In the year since they were released, nearly 2 million unique visitors have played them online, and our anecdotal observations suggest that most players are indeed engaging with cobot programming as envisioned. Separately, core project technologies have been adapted to power virtual robot programming curriculum that has served an additional 97,000 students through the pandemic and to the present day. Cobot game co-design methods have been adapted and used in continuing research, workforce development, and outreach programs; new games produced through these efforts have reached an additional 40,000 players and join existing games in building a critical mass of cobot-related activities to match diverse student interests and sustain engagement through “next activities”.
